isis.stitle: BRAKE COMPONENTS - QR-N QUICK RELEASE VALVE - SERVICE CHECKS

svcsubproc.title: Operating Test
svcsubproc.para: Apply 100 psi air pressure to the supply port of the QR-N and note that the brake chambers connected to the QR-N respond promptly.

step1.para: With 100 psi air pressure applied to the QR-N supply port, apply a soap solution to the exhaust port and around the junction of the upper and lower body halves.
Apply a soap solution to test for leakage at the exhaust port and between the 2 halves of the valve.

step2.para: No leakage is permitted between the body halves.
Leakage of greater than a 1 inch (25 mm) diameter bubble in 3 seconds at the exhaust port is unacceptable.

step1.para: Release the air pressure at the supply port and note that the brake chambers connected to the QR-N respond promptly and return to a zero air pressure condition.
If the QR-N does not function as described or if leakage is excessive, it is recommended that it be replaced with a new unit.

svcsubproc.title: Balance Test
svcsubproc.para: If slow brake release is experienced, the valve balance should be checked to determine if the QR-N should be replaced.

step1.para: Block the wheels of the vehicle.
Remove the QR-N supply line from the valve.
Install a "T" in the supply line fitting.
Reconnect the supply line along with a shut-off valve and 125 psi gauge into the "T."
Install a plug in one delivery port.
In the other delivery port, install a hose long enough to extend into a container of water.
Start the engine and build up air pressure to a minimum of 80 psi.

Start to open the shut off valve and watch for air bubbles in the container of water. A standard QR-N should show bubbles at 1 psi. A differential QR-N (spring and spring follower installed) should have bubbles at 3 psi ±1 psi.
If bubbles appear at pressures other than stated above, the valve is unacceptable and should be replaced.
